purpose: Lets exchange about great tools and code examples that could be useful for the TWIST-Hackdays
text: <@U59EH5MC1> set the channel purpose: Lets exchange about great tools and code examples that could be useful for the TWIST-Hackdays

--------------------------
SPARQL-Ressources for Linked Data:


	• W3C - SPARQL 1.1 Query Language: <https://www.w3.org/TR/sparql11-query/>
	• Intro von Adrian Gschwend: <http://presentations.zazuko.com/SPARQL/#3>
	• JSON for Linking Data: <https://json-ld.org/>
	• <https://github.com/zazuko/linked-data-training/blob/master/Resources.md>
	• Schulung Zazuko (12.02.2018): <https://github.com/zazuko/linked-data-training>
Using SPARQL with Phyton
	• SPARQL Kernel for Jupyter Notebooks: <https://twitter.com/betatim/status/985529724826017794>
	• Gastrodon: Toolkit to display, analyze & visualise data based on RDF. <https://github.com/paulhoule/gastrodon/blob/master/README.rst>

Basic Introduction:

	• Wikidata SPARQL queries: <https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Wikidata:SPARQL_query_service/queries>
	• Beispiele: <https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Wikidata:SPARQL_query_service/queries/examples>

Schweizer Beispiele:
	• Archival Linked Open Data: <http://data.alod.ch/search/>
	• GeoAdmin LD: <https://ld.geo.admin.ch/search/>
	• Linked Data for Dummies: <https://github.com/mmznr/DINAcon> ;
	• DINAcon Linked Data Challenges <https://gist.github.com/ktk/15fa867128c9c03a4ee27b559e362a27>
----------------------------------

---------------------------------
R-Ressources:
	• Journocode: <http://journocode.com/>
	• .Rddj: <https://rddj.info/>

	• R Einführung von visualisiert.: <http://archive.visualisiert.net/article/r-intro-installation/index.html>
	• Intro R-Tutorial nFrechen: <https://github.com/nFrechen/R-Tutorial-Deutsch>
	• DataCamp: <https://www.datacamp.com/>
	• Try R: <http://tryr.codeschool.com/>
	• R for Data Science (Hadley Wickham) <http://r4ds.had.co.nz/index.html>

Datenvisualisierung:

	• Getting started w/ data visualization in R w/ ggplot2: <http://www.storybench.org/getting-started-data-visualization-r-using-ggplot2/>
	• Analyze and visualize with tidyverse: <http://journocode.com/2017/08/16/datajournalism-workflow-ddj-r-rstats-rstudio-dplyr-ggplot2-tidyr/>
	• Timo: Communicating with data in the Tidyverse: <https://twitter.com/grssnbchr/status/973966997640724481>

Nice examples

	• Small multiples for the German elections 2017(morgenpost): <https://interaktiv.morgenpost.de/analyse-bundestagswahl-2017/data/btw17_analysis.html>
	• Swiss Maps: <https://github.com/zumbov2/RSwissMaps>
	• Exploring Heatmaps in R w/ Divvy Bike-Share :bike: Data: <http://austinwehrwein.com/data-visualization/heatmaps-with-divvy-data/>
	• Interactive mekko charts in R (Duc-Quang Nguyen): <https://dqn.website/post/interactive-mekko-charts-in-r/>

Acessing WebData and APIs (httr)

DataCamp: <https://www.datacamp.com/courses/working-with-web-data-in-r>
-------------------------------------

-----------------------------------
Mapping with QGIS
Main Tutorial: <http://www.qgistutorials.com/en/>

Nice examples und How-Tos:

Movement data:
	• Tutorial by Topi: <https://medium.com/@tjukanov/geogiffery-in-a-nutshell-introduction-to-qgis-time-manager-31bb79f2af19>
	
	• How to make a geogif: <http://www.statsmapsnpix.com/2017/12/how-to-make-geogif.html>
	
	• Movement data in GIS: Edge bundling for flow maps: <https://anitagraser.com/2017/10/08/movement-data-in-gis-8-edge-bundling-for-flow-maps/>
	• Animated routes with QGIS: <https://medium.com/@tjukanov/animated-routes-with-qgis-9377c1f16021>
	• Fadeout Effects! <https://anitagraser.com/2015/05/08/trajectory-animations-with-fadeout-effect/>



QGIS-Magic
	• Old raster maps to 3D <https://medium.com/@tjukanov/qgis-magic-old-raster-maps-to-3d-ddd0f550e0e8>

Big Geospatial Data:
	• White paper opengeospatial: <http://docs.opengeospatial.org/wp/16-131r2/16-131r2.html>

QGIS-Planet
	• <http://planet.qgis.org/planet/tag/style/>

QGIS 3
	• <https://north-road.com/2017/12/24/24-days-of-qgis-3-0-features/>
	• Shortcuts: <http://labs.webgeodatavore.com/partage/qgis-shortcuts/>
	• 3D-Ressourcen: Cities around the world with open CityGML datasets: <https://www.citygml.org/3dcities/>
	• 3D- Blogs: <https://www.lutraconsulting.co.uk/blog/2018/03/01/working-with-qgis-3d-part-1/>
	• Processing script template for QGIS3: <https://anitagraser.com/2018/03/25/processing-script-template-for-qgis3/>
----------------------------------------------------

by <@UBN6K2U3Z>: The best Python link I have is <https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0020/> :man_in_lotus_position: And seriously, installing the interpreter or an IDE like Jupyter or PyCharm is the best way to get going. If you're planning to dig into data science, beginners tend to find Anaconda easiest to install Pandas, Numpy, Scikit-Learn, etc. on your local machine. But then again, these days you can even more easily use any language you want in the cloud.. There's a wealth of knowledge from the Swiss Python community available at <https://www.python-summit.ch/pages/recordings.html>

attachments.title: D3.js - Data-Driven Documents
attachments.text: D3 is a JavaScript library for visualizing data with HTML, SVG, and CSS.
